Can you give an example of how this platform plugin will be used, and why?

- Dell hardware stores all reset/reboot reasons (including cold and warm cpu resets) in a register. This hardware register value persists till next reset/reboot occurs. 
- As the hardware doesn't have a way to detect fast-boot, following the fast-boot, hardware reset-cause register would end up having the previous reset reason value which is a stale value.
- This plugin is added to find this situation. Otherwise, following fast-boot, the reset reason API (that reads the data from hardware) returns incorrect reset reason.

For example:-
1. Run 1:  User power-cycled the switch. .Hardware reset-cause register has value 0x11 which means power-cycle.
2. Run 2: reboot command executed from SONiC. Hardware reset-cause register value changed to 0x55 which means warm-cpu reboot.
3. Run 3: hardware watchdog resets the switch. Hardware reset-cause register value changed to 0x33 which means watchdog reset.
4. Run 4: fast-boot command executed from SONiC. Hardware reset-cause register value remains un-changed as 0x33 which means watchdog reset.
5. Run 5: show reboot reason call reset reason API which refers the hardware and returns watchdog reset. This is incorrect. The above change addresses this problem.
Please include this change for 201811 branch also.

I'm now contemplating changing this as follows:

- Instead of calling `systemctl reset-failed <service>` on each service in the list, just call `systemctl reset-failed` once to clear the failed state of ALL failed services. This will also ensure all dependent services are removed from the failed state.

Thoughts, anyone?

Edit: I made the change in commit #ab28455

@avi-milner: Are you asking that I revert back to the original solution? What about dependent services? What if they (synd, teamd, etc.) are in the failed state? I don't believe they will get restarted.

> @avi-milner: Are you asking that I revert back to the original solution? What about dependent services? What if they (synd, teamd, etc.) are in the failed state? I don't believe they will get restarted.

Are syncd and teamd systemd controlled? In either case, if there are dependent services, then we need to have a list of them and reset-failed those as well if we feel we should. A blind reset-failed for all services inside a sonic device, is not the right thing to do.

@nikos-github: Yes. All Docker containers are controlled by their own service. Multiple services are dependent upon SwSS (syncd, teamd, dhcp_relay, radv, snmp), so when SwSS restarts it will also restart its dependent services.

@avi-milner: What do you see wrong with removing all services from the failed list upon reloading config? Reloading config is pretty much like wiping the slate clean. Why not also reset the failed status of all services at that time?

@jleveque As I mentioned earlier, this is not the right approach. Resetting all failed services in the sonic device through the use of `systemctl reset-failed` is not correct. The services need to be explicitly specified. Not all services are under sonic's control in the switch and therefore no such assumption should be made.

Sorry for the confusion earlier. I seem to have gotten your responses mixed up.

@nikos-github: So you believe resetting all failed services upon reloading the configuration is not an assumption we can make? Like I said earlier, reloading configuration pretty much "wipes the slate clean"; at which point we would want to try to restart *all* services, even those which may have failed (which may have been due to bad configuration). Can you provide an example of a service which you would *not* want to remove from the failed list when reloading configuration?

@jleveque This really depends on how the user has configured their Linux system. We should try to restart all failed sonic services or at least the ones controlled or are dependent by config reload. Not `all` failed services in the system in general. When sonic configuration is reloaded, it should contain itself to sonic services. `systemctl reset-failled` will reset ALL failed services in the system whether they are sonic related or not.

@nikos-github: Please review my latest iteration. I now obtain a list of failed services and only restart each one if it is a service we will be attempting to restart (or a dependency thereof) by explicitly checking against a list.

Hi Sunny,

"show runningconfiguration interface" and "show runningconfiguration interfaces" are two different commands. One ends with "intreface" and other one with "interface**s**" 

```
[admin@lnos-x1-a-csw06:~$ show runningconfiguration interface --verbose
Command: sonic-cfggen -d --var-json PORT
...
admin@lnos-x1-a-csw06:~$ show runningconfiguration interfaces --verbose
Command: sonic-cfggen -d --var-json INTERFACE
....
](url)
```
I think these are NOT intuitive, we should change them.
I think we should correct them as "show runningconfiguration ports" and "show runningconfiguration interfaces"  for PORT and INTERFACE respectively.

> Hi Sunny,
> "show runningconfiguration interface" and "show runningconfiguration interfaces" are two different commands. One ends with "intreface" and other one with "interfaces"
> [admin@lnos-x1-a-csw06:~$ show runningconfiguration interface --verbose
> Command: sonic-cfggen -d --var-json PORT
> ...
> admin@lnos-x1-a-csw06:~$ show runningconfiguration interfaces --verbose
> Command: sonic-cfggen -d --var-json INTERFACE
> ....
> ](url)
> 
> I think these are NOT intuitive, we should change them.
> I think we should correct them as "show runningconfiguration ports" and "show runningconfiguration interfaces"  for PORT and INTERFACE respectively.

@vasant17 , I think it is confusing. Especially since we can give short names in CLI command like '`show running int`'. Kindly change to `port `for the first case

Hi Sunny,

I do understand the issue. Infact "show runningconfiguration int" is an invalid command, as long as the last word in CLI has ambiguous branches, it does NOT accept it has valid command. And "show runningconfiguration ?" does display interface and interfaces options and descriptions.

I need to evaluate after effects of changing interface to port. Hence I will take it up as a different PR.

Just for our records. Original PR when this change went in:
https://github.com/Azure/sonic-utilities/pull/557

> I completely agree with @prsunny.
> 
> @vasant17: Please rename the `show runningconfiguration interface` command to `show runningconfiguration port`. This will prevent a lot of confusion.


Hi Joe,

Thanks for looking into this. I do agree with the issue, but please note that it has NOT been introduced in this PR. Instead we should have caught it while reviewing https://github.com/Azure/sonic-utilities/pull/557

Nevertheless, I am working on fixing it, but all that I am saying is: I do NOT want to mix these issues. I have created another pull request to rename " interface" to "ports" in "show runningconfiguration ..." CLI command. Please review it https://github.com/Azure/sonic-utilities/pull/600

Please let me know if you have any other comments on this PR. Once PR #600 is merged, I will rebase this one.

@vasant17: I understand that you didn't introduce the naming issue. I take responsibility for missing that when reviewing #557. I appreciate you changing it to prevent future confusion, and I agree it is better to make the change part of a separate PR. :)

@yxieca: Now that https://github.com/Azure/sonic-buildimage/pull/2852 has been merged into the 201811 branch, this PR should also be cherry-picked into the 201811 branch. Hopefully it will pick cleanly.

I can see similiar commands in sonic_installer, can you check them as well?

            run_command("docker exec -i bgp pkill -9 zebra")
            run_command("docker exec -i bgp pkill -9 bgpd")

sonic_installer does have calls to `pkill -9 ...`, but no calls to `docker kill ...`, which is what this PR addresses. For the calls to `pkill -9 ...`, we will need to address these when adding the auto-restart mechanism to these containers.

what if the service is going to be restarted before it was stopped?
With this patch we introduce the race condition here.

@pavel-shirshov: If someone or something had called `systemctl restart ...` on one of these services and this script called `systemctl stop ...` while the restart operation was still in progress, whichever command was run last (in this case, `systemctl stop ...`) would override the pending `systemctl restart ...`. Do you have some other concern?

@jleveque 
Current behavior is following:
1. We kill a process/processes inside of the docker container
2. We stop the container itself because we afraid the process would be restarted by supervisorctl inside of the container (fix me if I'm wrong here)

So I think if we don't fast enough to stop the container, but supervisorctl restarted just killed processes already?

These processes are not set to be restarted by supervisor inside the containers. The restart mechanism uses a supervisor event listener to listen for processes exiting, which then causes supervisor to exit and subsequently the container itself. Then, *systemd* will restart the entire container. Here we're killing the *container*, then stopping the systemd service to prevent it from restarting the container.
@jleveque , can you identify the branches that needed to be backported?

One concern here is regarding devices with small flash drives. Currently in SONiC, /tmp is not mounted to tmpfs. There is the possibility that copying the image file to /tmp will occupy disk space such that there will not be enough space left to install the image.

> One concern here is regarding devices with small flash drives. Currently in SONiC, /tmp is not mounted to tmpfs. There is the possibility that copying the image file to /tmp will occupy disk space such that there will not be enough space left to install the image.

Please check the change in commit 2, now we use 'bash -C' to get rid of the dependency on executable  attribute

@ds952811: I am not familiar with the `-C` option for bash, but upon looking into it, it is a synonym for `noclobber`, which simply prevents accidentally overwriting files by redirection (https://www.tldp.org/LDP/abs/html/options.html). Have you tested this? Is there more information I'm not aware of?

> @ds952811: I am not familiar with the `-C` option for bash, but upon looking into it, it is a synonym for `noclobber`, which simply prevents accidentally overwriting files by redirection (https://www.tldp.org/LDP/abs/html/options.html). Have you tested this? Is there more information I'm not aware of?

This is an alternative approach to launch bash for script interpretation on a file without executable attribute requirement.

e.g. <Sorry, I do not know how to stop the GUI to get these following logs formatted inappropriately>
admin@sonic:~$ cat hello.sh
#!/bin/bash

echo Hi
admin@sonic:~$ chmod -x hello.sh
admin@sonic:~$ ls -l hello.sh
-rw-r--r-- 1 admin admin 21 Jul  4 01:14 hello.sh
admin@sonic:~$ bash -C hello.sh
Hi
admin@sonic:~$

Here is a detailed example of sonic_installer

-----------------------------------------------------

admin@sonic:/tmp$ ls -l sonic-broadcom.bin
-rw-r--r-- 1 admin admin 725116182 Jul  4 09:23 sonic-broadcom.bin
admin@sonic:/tmp$ sudo sonic_installer install sonic-broadcom.bin
New image will be installed, continue? [y/N]: y
Command: bash -C ./sonic-broadcom.bin
Verifying image checksum ... OK.
Preparing image archive ... OK.
Installing SONiC in SONiC
ONIE Installer: platform: x86_64-broadcom-r0
onie_platform: x86_64-accton_as7326_56x-r0
Not installing SONiC version sonic_2.0_daily_190702_1640_158-dirty-20190702.164237, as current running SONiC has the same version

Command: grub-set-default --boot-directory=/host 0

@ds952811: Can you please provide a link to documentation for this behavior of the `-C` flag in bash? I cannot find it in any man pages or other documentation.

> @ds952811: Can you please provide a link to documentation for this behavior of the `-C` flag in bash? I cannot find it in any man pages or other documentation.

It turns out that we don't need '-C', I was wrong about it, it's not a known option of bash, we could just remove '-C' and it's still working.

e.g.
root@sonic:~# sonic_installer install sonic-broadcom.bin
New image will be installed, continue? [y/N]: y
Command: bash ./sonic-broadcom.bin
Verifying image checksum ... OK.

It might be clear for people more familiar with this code. I have some questions:

- It is unclear why DEVICE_NEIGHBOR table would contain all 'active' ports
- If a port is enabled, but link is down or haven't discovered neighbor yet, will the port be included in the table?

If any 'enabled' table is not included in the list when the command is executed. When the port later becomes 'active', will it miss ecn configuration?
@wendani: Can you answer Ying's questions above? I am also unclear as to why the change from PORT table to DEVICE_NEIGHBOR table is better.

PORT table contains all ports of the device
DEVICE_NEIGHBOR table contains all ports of the device which have a change to be activated some time.
We don't need to spend any time on ports, which are going to be down all time.
Thanks for the answer @pavel-shirshov. Ports not in the DEVICE_NEIGHBOR are not enabled. Its ps is !ena on brcm platform

Any comments before we merge this PR?

> With this PR, is the current psuutil completely deprecated? If so, should it be removed? Also, do we foresee a possible future need to write to the PSU control registers? If so, this utility should be renamed "psuutil" instead of "psushow".

No, current per platform's psuutil is still used by PSU daemon. Sure, we can rename it to psuutil from psushow.
I'm not referring to the psuutil.py plugin, but rather the executable file which resides under the `psuutil` directory in this repo. Does this new application supplant that?

> I'm not referring to the psuutil.py plugin, but rather the executable file which resides under the `psuutil` directory in this repo. Does this new application supplant that?

Yes, the script/psushow is to take replace of the psuutil package. So we need to remove it.
Take another thought, shall we retain a way to get information directly rather than from DB?

I think we need to retain a way to get information directly from the hardware for debugging purposes. An earlier discussions, the thought was we could have separate, simple scripts inside the pmon docker for this purpose.

Agree. I would suggest split the task into two PRs.
The first PR should implement a new script to support get PSU infor from DB directly which is covered by this PR in the "script/psushow".
The second PR is to remove the psuutil package, and add another option in "script/psushow" to support get PSU from hardware. Also need to support option '-v' to show the version and option '-n' to show the number of PSUs like what current psuutil package did. May rename "script/psushow"to "script/psuutil".

@jleveque : Resolved the conflict. Request you to kindly review and merge it.
@prsunny  and  @jleveque : Anything else required on this? Or, can it be merged?
Is there a location where the table # of 5000 use for mgmt-vrf is mentioned ?  I checked the mgmt-vrf HLD document but could not find a reference other than "1" in the example linux commands.
@a-barboza : We shall update the document once if the PR is merged. Just waiting to see if there could be any changes in the CLI before merging based on any review comments.

@a-barboza : Some of your questions from PR472 that are relevant for this PR are answered here.

1) Why restart NTP ? (These changes are for SNMP ?)
<<Kannan>> This is not part of SNMP PR. This is part of this 463 PR. Once if 463 is merged, 472 PR will contain only mvrf SNMP CLI changes.

2) clear_mgmt command: There are some new commands common to all mgmt-vrf ?
MGMT_INTERFACE, MGMT_VRF_CONFIG tables ?
<<Kannan>> This command is an easy way to clear both the tables. 

3) There is a new "--gw" option? Why is this only for eth0 ? Can Front Panel (In-Band) port be part of the mgmt-vrf ?
<<Kannan>> As of now, eth0 alone will be part of mvrf; not front panel ports. This "gw" is to add default route for mvrf which is already there in config_db as part of MGMT_INTERFACE. We just added CLI for supporting that.  This CLI enhancement is only for mvrf and hence other non mvrf options are not being touched.

4) Is the table #1001 reserved for mgmt-vrf, or is it Table# 1 ?
<<Kannan>> Table 5000 is reserved for mvrf. CLI in this PR is already corrected to use 5000 (not 1001).

5) Will be replied in PR472.

6) Is the Curl, Wget, SSH also supported for mgmt-vrf ?
<<Kannan>> Yes, all applications are supported for mgmt-vrf. Those applications do not need any enhancement. Users can do "cgexec -g l3mdev:mgmt COMMAND" for running any application from the device. Similarly, users can establish any application connections to the device from external network as well.

7) Where is the mgmtvrf_ntpq command ?
<<Kannan>> mgmtvrf_ntpq is removed now in this PR463.  Once if this PR463 is merged, same changes will be there in 472.

@kannankvs: thanks for the replies. For answer 3 above: Will the HLD for management vrf be updated to state the following " As of now, eth0 alone will be part of mvrf; not front panel ports" ?

one question: are we supposing to have single port binding as a string or as a list with one element in it?

@stcheng: I believe that if there is ever a potential for multiple values, the value should *always* be a list, even if it happens to contain only one element. After more thought, the only way to get into this situation is to manually create an acl.json file with a string instead of a list of strings as the value for `ports`. This should not be an issue, as long as acl.json is created properly. We need to ensure this is clearly stated in the schema documentation. I will revert this PR. This field should always be a list.
thanks. with 'future' enhancement, we could have more protections on the format of the database and we could prevent such issues from happening fundamentally

@ishidawataru: This change doesn't appear to speed up bash completion at all. Typing `show` and pressing tab twice hangs for 2.651 seconds before displaying results. Have you noticed any improvement with bash completion, or with anything else, for that matter?

I am currently building from the head of the master branch of sonic-buildimage (currently commit https://github.com/Azure/sonic-buildimage/commit/2b01beb7d4f5ab5cf6c864dd6640ab9d8f6770df), and I am still seeing `from pkg_resources import load_entry_point` being called.

Hi kirankella, with your changes, I have another problem. When I use the command “sudo config interface PortChannel0001 shutdown”, the terminal prompts that the interface name is invalid, as shown below:
admin@sonic:~$ **sudo config interface PortChannel0001 shutdown**
Usage: config interface shutdown [OPTIONS]

Error: Interface name is invalid. Please enter a  valid interface name!!
admin@sonic:~$ **show interfaces portchannel**
Flags: A - active, I - inactive, Up - up, Dw - Down, N/A - not available, S - selected, D - deselected
  No.  Team Dev         Protocol     Ports
-----  ---------------  -----------  --------------
 0001  PortChannel0001  LACP(A)(Up)  Ethernet108(S)
admin@sonic:~$

So, when checking the validity of the interface name, should it also include the PORTCHANNEL table, not just in the PORT table?

Is it related to the docker corruption issue: https://github.com/Azure/sonic-buildimage/issues/2382?

As far as I can tell, the timeout is seemingly caused by a race condition in the redis database, more likely around the listening socket. I need to run more tests to figure out the exact issue. But since this issue is discovered, I need to put some protection code while investigating.

Even though this issue was triggered 1 in 3 times with syncd warm shutdown on 7260cx3 platform, warm restart syncd test won't trigger it. Which means that the syncd pre-shutdown is part of the trigger in the warm reboot sequence, but not the only trigger to this issue.
